Air is a quick-paced entertainer with glib dialogue, humour and a wonderful sense of nostalgia for the 1980s.
Once you’ve made peace with those really narrow parameters, what you see on screen – ie virtually nothing of Jordan himself – kind of works.
There’s not an ounce of fat on this film’s physique, and Affleck keeps the pace moving even though everything that’s happening is entirely driven by the dialogue.

Affleck is a fine actor and a better-than-fine director. As an actor since childhood, his skill at selecting the right actors and allowing them to do their best is to be expected. He also has an exceptional sense of narrative structure.
Affleck, the cast, crew and script put you in a time capsule and take you back to the ’80s.
Ben Affleck's got a great feel for this real-life stories.

Nostalgia is the only reason I can think of to explain why old friends Ben Affleck and Matt Damon reteamed for a movie that so artlessly sets out to make us love shoe company Nike for buttering up a college hoops star better than Adidas or Converse.
While much of Affleck's casting choices in Air err on the side of superb, one pivotal choice is repeatedly jarring: He doesn't cast Michael Jordan.
The script is pacy, the tone is consistent, and Affleck’s deft direction commands a raft of skilful performances from an ensemble who rarely puts a foot wrong.
For all its affable charm, there’s something slippery and disingenuous about this film.
"Air" is effortlessly entertaining, but it wants to be about more than just the marketing triumph of an underdog shoe company.
The film certainly invites fists to be pumped in celebration. It is less certain Air offers any meaningful critique of the society that gave us the sacred gutty.
Affleck’s return to the director’s chair is an exceptional success, stimulated by its script and cast.

The decision to deny Jordan a character presence... conspicuously muzzles a pivotal character and it’s clumsily out of step with a movie that is otherwise the definition of carefully considered, precisely told, error-free film-making.

As much as we can talk about the thematic resonance of Air, its impact is dependent on your personal connection to Michael Jordan. It’s like going to church as an atheist — you might be able to follow the story, but its meaning is lost.

Air mainly takes place in drab offices, yet the cast’s expert performances transform those spaces much in the same way that Michael Jordan transformed courts and sneaker racks -- by turning them into sites of magic.

A solid exercise in brand mythology, putting the “commercial” in commercial filmmaking, but one with such a predestined outcome that all its Mad Men-esque wheeling and dealing can’t mask the sensation of all its characters running in place.
It’s a feel-good fable for a culture that doesn’t know how not to win, and it’s going to be huge.
The film wants to be a wing-ding entertainment, but it also strives to say Something Important. The first half of that equation is what makes the movie eminently worth watching.
Air is great. Pitch-perfect, deeply entertaining.

The boldest thing I can say about Air is that it follows the tried-and-true underdog sports movie formula, only none of its main characters even attempt a shot much less sink the game-winner at the buzzer.

Director Ben Affleck slam dunks a film about a basketball sneaker (the Air Jordan) and it’s the first all-star Oscar contender of 2023, an outrageously entertaining classic with Affleck, Matt Damon, Viola Davis and a cast of MVPs at the top of their game.
"Air" is a meaningful movie but an unsatisfying one.
Ben Affleck and Matt Damon’s story of Nike’s paradigm-shifting deal with Michael Jordan is both a great time at the theater and an odd valorization of an already all-powerful brand
Air is thoroughly entertaining, even if it never really maximizes its alluring potential.
Even given the benefit of every possible doubt, Air is pretty thin.
It plays like pure television by an Aaron Sorkin disciple, and there is no reason whatsoever to see this on the big screen.

The only problem facing Air is that people may be expecting a bigger movie. This is a modest, entertaining behind-the-scenes film about the marketing whiz who believed in Jordan when he was still a rookie
Coupled with a near-fetishistic attachment to the material indicators of the decade, it’s hard to land on a reason for any of this to exist beyond a goosing up of Nike’s own image.
The film is a love letter to consumerism wrapped in a corporate legend, inside a feelgood workplace comedy. The result is so deeply un-dystopian...
This is the most Ben Affleck movie: taking queasy material and making it earnest, sentimental, likeable and soft-around-the-edges.
An energetic take on an iconic sneaker – if not the icon himself.

Ben Affleck’s drama excludes Jordan from his own story.

The entire cast does some of their best work.

Watching Sonny and Deloris square off here is where the film's real heart and tension are.

A well-oiled machine of a movie, as slick and convincing as its obvious show-me-the-money inspiration. It had me at, “Just Do It.”
This movie, in short, kneels at the altar of high capitalism.
It’s far and away the most likable film released so far this year.

Consider this framing all in the name of a thrilling cinematic experience that serves the main objective of every film: to tell a great story. And “Air” is a riotous, worthwhile and surprisingly heartfelt film that does just that.
A biopic with real sole.
For the most part, [Air] is as smooth and reliable as one of Jordan’s buzzer-beating, fadeaway jumpers.
A soulless dramatization of how a giant corporation convinced a promising NBA rookie to make its already wealthy and well-off board members, CEOs, and salespeople even wealthier and set for life.
This film winds up looking like the most expensive in-house corporate promo in history: shallow, parochial and obtuse.
Ben Affleck’s film reminds viewers that the boardroom game can be as tense, unpredictable, and exhilarating as the one on the court.
Affleck’s treatise on the film industry and the perils of celebrity, shoehorned into a biopic of a brand... Affleck applies just the right elements to make it sing.

A rousing underdog saga that—like Ben Affleck’s prior directorial efforts Gone Baby Gone, The Town, and Argo—has the type of snappy energy and charm that should earn it a long post-theatrical shelf life.
“Air” is that most familiar and satisfying of movie stories: believing in yourself and persuading other people to accept your quest, despite long odds and questionable methods.
It’s ridiculous how entertaining “Air” is given that it’s about shoes, even if it works overtime to persuade you that it’s also about other, nobler truths, too.

Air is smartly acted and agreeably paced, a drama of invention that warmly invites the audience into an interesting process... [But] I am finding it hard to be moved by stories of lucrative business. Congrats, I guess?

“Air” lands like a classic Michael Jordan dunk – you can even imagine Affleck’s tongue wagging and legs splayed in mid-jump akin to his Airness.

An engaging and entertaining trip down memory lane and behind-the-scenes story that turns a seemingly minor moment in sports history — the development of a shoe that became a pop-cultural touchstone — into something often funny and occasionally moving.

A crowd-pleaser made with panache and smarts. Matt Damon is immensely appealing as a middle-aged basketball guru who bets everything on landing Michael Jordan, and director Ben Affleck produces one of his most irresistibly entertaining dramas.
Alex Convery’s script frames the story half as a Moneyball-like cracking of the sports world’s cosmic code, half as a Jerry Maguire-style triumph against the corporate odds.

Air is shot through with an infectious energy, but it’s more poignant for the way that it rhymes the histories of its actors in the public eye with all that Nike’s creatives were struggling to reconcile when they were chasing after Michael Jordan.
In his fifth feature film, Ben Affleck’s talents exceed expectations. He’s grown as an actor and director but is best when doing both.

It’s a lot of fun, way more than a film about a large company striving to make even more money should be. But it could have paid a little more heed to #3 on Nike’s famous list of ten corporate principles: “Break the rules.”
Affleck remains one of the directors who can disguise a powerful parable as giddy, crowd-pleasing entertainment.

The banter in Convery’s script is entertaining, but it’s truly the actors under Affleck’s excellent direction that makes “Air” feel like something special. It doesn’t nail every scene or sentiment; but when the film is good (which is often), it’s on fire.
Not a slam dunk, but scores enough points.

A by-the-numbers biopic that does a disservice to its star and subject, and sorely missing a killer soundtrack. Watch The Man Who Fell To Earth instead.

Exasperating viewing for fans and certain to baffle newcomers, it's a curious, imaginative thing, but who exactly is it for?
