Human moments punctuate and overlap with the sillier ones, giving Sword of Truth a sense of generosity and an emotional core in addition to its laughs.

I wanted to discard every element of the plot and just hang out with the characters over coffee for an hour-something that speaks to both Shelton's gift with character/performances and how little I cared about what actually happens in this movie.
Its concerns are person-to-person rather than broadly political in the end, which is far from surprising in a Shelton film. On this modest scale, it finds reason for hope.
Everyone onscreen is so good at this kind of work that one wishes more tightly scripted comedy screenplays had such savory dialogue, or inspired character conceptions.

For decades Kent Jones has been one of the most eloquent and perceptive film critics in the U.S.; with this devastating chamber drama... he also proves himself to be a keen observer of psychology and American social mores.
We usually expect that a film named after its protagonist will sooner or later reveal everything about that person, give us the whole woman; Diane, by contrast, comes in pieces
Diane is a sublime puzzle of a movie, resolving itself without completely yielding its secrets.
The reason Diane (the film) exists is not to propose and then solve a mystery, but to engage with Diane (the person).
"Diane" is a sharp, attuned, quiet stunner that underplays at every turn.
"Diane" affords Martin, Parsons and company the chance to do honest, low-keyed work with material worth the effort.
[It's] a remarkable film that will see Diane through many losses, and some gains, with her to the last.
It's a rarity, and a real pleasure, to find a movie that presents without condescension rural working-class people, especially women.
Place manages to twist herself physically and emotively into such pretzel-like knots I was astonished by the emotional magnitude of what it was she was doing.
While "Diane" is perhaps 96 of the most depressing minutes on film this year, its quiet honesty is compelling. treating aging and death with a respect to the inevitability of both.
The more adventurous or open-hearted may step into this film and find a kind of translucent everyday poetry.
[A] naturalistic portrait of service and self-sacrifice by way of a quietly astonishing title performance by Mary Kay Place.
With "Diane," as in life, it feels like nothing's going on, but everything's going on.
The sharp-edged bonds that hold a family and a community together are examined intimately but vaguely in this lyrical melodrama by the writer and director Kent Jones.

Diane is consistently absorbing but low-key, that won't appeal to some people . It's a compassionate character study that showcases one of the most endearing of all contemporary actresses, and that's what makes it well worth seeing
A meticulously detailed portrait of the type of woman who never gets a movie made about her.
Kent has assembled a superb group of character actors here, who tell lived-in stories with extraordinary sensitivity and grace.

What looks at first like a solid, well-carpentered exercise in downbeat indie realism ends up, by dint of its unexpected tonal and temporal leaps and sudden formal ruptures, in less easily definable territory.
The movie is populated by people we seldom see in mainstream films, so seldom that we may not remember the pleasure we've been missing.

Jones fills her existential space with a bracing, though never unfeeling, inquiry into what it feels like to confront the steady drip of accumulating pain, and loss, and no longer being needed as we age.
Trying to forestall our loneliness is what connects us. That's not a depressing conclusion - it's the beginning of a design for living. In its mundane way, Diane gives you a glimpse of the sublime.
It's Place's subtle, moment-to-moment performance that provides the balance to save Diane from ho-hum tedium.
Mary Kay Place... gets the role of a lifetime in Diane.
Mary Kay Place delivers one of the year's best performances in this shattering character study from writer-director Kent Jones in a narrative feature debut that sneaks up and floors you.
In the context of the modern multiplex, "Diane" amounts to an act of cinematic bravery, not just in its choice of tough-sell material, but in the patience with which Jones tends it.
If the overall effect of this tender yet unsparing movie is a bit depressive, it's nothing its maker should apologize for.
Compared to Diane's rather staid first half, this ambitious formalist turn is welcome. But fittingly, perhaps, for a film so fixated with death, it's too little, too late.

A loose-limbed, deceptively modest portrait of small-town Massachusetts as seen through the eyes of a stoic septuagenarian widow, whose loved ones are falling sick and dropping dead at a rather alarming rate.
Life is often meant to come undone, meant for the center to not hold...Diane is about loss and recovery, and the spinning of the world long after we die.
Mary Kay Place is marvelous in the leading role, and her screen presence is so arm and comforting, we think we know her. Jones uses that familiarity, brilliantly.
Excellent direction, dialogue and ensemble acting make what's on view a totally captivating look at the passage of time and last chapter of life.
It's a great performance, and a studio would be wise to pick this film up so that the rest of the world can see it.
Kent Jones conditions us to expect that Diane will follow its protagonist to her death, with little overt plot to speak off, in a quiet refutation of the three-act contrivances of most cinema.
The past hangs over "Diane" not just as a burden or nostalgia (though it can be that too), but as an enthralling and entangling reminder of life's mystery.
It's a pinhole portrait of life on Earth; a non-judgmental story about trying to reconcile meaning with meaningless before the well runs dry and it rains again.
Raw, real and quietly affecting.
A strong work and one of the peaks of this year's Tribeca slate.
Always worth seeing these two actors, but not necessarily in this movie.
An apocalyptic septuagenarian romance that leads with its heart rather than its head, "The Tomorrow Man" is warm in spots but never quite comes together.
Ronnie? She's just looking for someone to sing Muskrat Love with. If you are as well, this quaint, doting film might be your thing.
The Tomorrow Man gives off a feeling of having seen it all before.
For all its eccentricities, The Tomorrow Man plays it too safe.
There's a lack of chemistry that makes for a listlessness of narrative.
John Lithgow and Blythe Danner make an offbeat and winning combination, with total belief that they're in a really good movie. Unfortunately, they're not.
The movie's ending could be called a twist. But it's really more of a belly flop.
Debut writer-director Noble Lincoln Jones' dramedy is a delightful oddity in our superhero era.
If you cherish the rare opportunity to watch magnificent actors as perfect as Blythe Danner and John Lithgow giving it all they've got, in a film about grown-ups, then the line starts here.
The actors bring a great deal of humanity to keep a wobbly script from going too far off balance.
A cloying, at times disturbing tale of two dotty seniors whose eccentricities unexpectedly mesh.

Makes some astute observations about the coping mechanisms we use to protect ourselves from the world, with Jones eliciting solid performances from John Lithgow and Blythe Danner as two troubled senior citizens embarking on a tenuous courtship.
While the film's last 30 seconds are refreshing, they hardly redeem the previous 90 minutes of utter predictability.
The film is content to peddle the naïve notion that love is the panacea for all that ails you.
[T]he film's packaging has an attractive simplicity - amplifying an overall effect of everyday strangeness that's finally more reassuring than truly bizarre.
Keeps chasing a quirky scenario that never settles in.

Noble Jones' first feature... would have worked superbly as a half-hour Twilight Zone episode, but this December-December love story between two mild eccentrics in a small town is remarkably unremarkable.
What might have made for either a thrilling, high-stakes drama or, at the very least, an intelligent comedy, ends up wildly uneven.

Although sometimes it gets bogged down in the details of drilling, The Hummingbird Project extracts enough entertainment value from an unpromising premise, greatly helped by Jesse Eisenberg finding the humanity in his hustler.

Part thriller, part family drama, part satirical commentary on the way that the pursuit of wealth is a cultural cancer that taints everything it touches, The Hummingbird Project is no less compelling for its odd mishmash of components.
It sounds deeply unappetizing, but in fact, it's really enjoyable to watch. It's about obsession in a way I really like...
It's typical of a movie, written and directed by the Canadian film-maker Kim Nguyen, that hits all the right genre beats while consistently reaching for something more.
It's the kind of verbose corporate parable David Mamet would sit down to write after a heavy night on the sauce.
It may be a modest indie film, but it deserves a broad audience. Highly recommended.
That the film is watchable at all, as incongruity, improbability and incomprehensibility accumulate, is a tribute to Canadian director Kim Nguyen, skilfully negotiating a script by Kim Nguyen.
A finance story that stretches beyond the usual coke-addled Wall Street traders.
It's an odd tale, but in its sneaky way, an unexpectedly engaging one.
[A]n invigorating snapshot of greed that examines how far competitors will go to gain even the slightest fraction of an edge over their rivals in the stock market.
What makes The Hummingbird Project so intriguing is that it explores areas of business - and of industrial espionage - so esoteric that it's hard to imagine that it's really a business model.
The Hummingbird Project runs a lot thicker and deeper than that fiber-optic cable.
And so you will get no Scorsesian tracking shots of firecracker trading floors, no giddy frat boy Champagne-shaking antics; this is a slow-boil thriller coursing with melancholy.
A believability problem hampers this potentially fascinating story about the high-tech Wild West.
Somewhere, buried within the innards of writer/director Kim Nguyen's The Hummingbird Project, is the skeleton of a compelling techno-thriller.
"The Hummingbird Project" basically works; it's intriguing; the actors play it just straight enough to make it feel like a fact-based drama (though it isn't) with a few darkly comic details.
It all feels a bit contrived.
It may be haphazard and loosely focused. But thanks to Skarsgård it's never really boring.
At once an offbeat comedy and a satisfyingly weird thriller.

It's a lot to pack into a movie of less than two hours of running time. To Nguyen's credit, he balances the elements of his screenplay with such skill that the audience doesn't get too lost in the weeds.
[Skarsgård is] often the best part of anything he's in, but here he's uncanny.
Whatever it takes to keep a techno hellraiser on its feet, this humdrum Hummingbird doesn't have it, despite the efforts of Eisenberg and Skarsgård to breathe some life into it.
Sometimes funny, sometimes smart, always watchable, but perhaps the film's dedication to turning a clever tale into something profound was a miscalculation.
When a story is predicated on something as dramatically inert as laying high-speed fiber-optic cable, it requires characters more fully fleshed out than those on presentation here.
This one works overtime, shifting gears repeatedly without once providing enough substance for the viewer to engage.
That so much might be riding on so little is a critical irony that The Hummingbird Project recognizes but ultimately fumbles.
While its banter keeps the scenes moving along briskly, Vinny talks in that scammy "we're all going to be millionaires" way you've seen in umpteen other finance sagas.
At its best The Hummingbird Project is a parable about failure, but one that ultimately undercuts itself with redeeming goo.
A smartly entertaining and unexpectedly human film...
"The Hummingbird Project" may be too committed to its popcorn mechanics to double as a truly brainy exposé, but it pays other dividends.
Throughout, the film can't decide what attitude to strike toward its characters' evident greed.

A defiantly odd thriller involving esoteric subject matter, The Hummingbird Project tells a familiar story of ambition and greed with enough eccentricity that the movie's strangeness becomes one of its chief attributes.
An entertaining vehicle for vivid performances by both actors.
There's a good reason why no one's ever made a movie about this before - in fact, there are probably a few.
There's a fascinating performance near the center of The Hummingbird Project, but director Kim Nguyen never finds the urgency in his feels-true-but-isn't narrative.
Though this intriguing genre-hybrid might be just a little too odd for more mainstream success, this is a promising step in the right direction for Nguyen.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It has a scrappy, indie feel that I like...not for everyone...but an honest and compassionate account, the pain and the ecstasy of the creative process...

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It'd be easy to map Gilliam on to Grisoni, a film-maker dogged by his artistic misfires and the mess left in their wake. Really, though, he's Quixote, stuck in a noble past and wilfully disconnected from a present that jostles uncomfortably close.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: A staggering misfire that's both unambitious and bloated.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It's a messy, unfocused film that seems so in awe of its own existence that it can't quite summon the energy to tell a worthwhile story.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Neither a splendid phoenix from the ashes nor a complete failure, The Man Who Killed Don Quixote is erratic, occasionally inspired, occasionally dull, but shot through with a grandiose sense of ambition.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: The melancholy is the saving grace, one man out of time immortalising another. Gilliam refrains from explicit meta, but winks over the fourth wall.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It's fitfully entertaining. I will say that Jonathan Pryce is perfect in [this] role.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: "The end result is messy, ragged, uneven, all over the place. But it's also the single best Gilliam film to hit theaters in 20 years."

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: This is Gilliam at his most Gilliam, and that's fine, but there's nothing left to say.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: So after all that heartache, it looks as though Gilliam's dream has turned into something of a nightmare.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It's exactly the kind of odd, reality-skewing fantasy you'd expect from the inventive Gilliam.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: To anyone who has followed the parabolic arcs of Gilliam's career, it's a fascinating text; to the more casual viewer, it might come off only as a meandering mess.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: The story doesn't follow Cervantes in every detail, but there is no mistaking Gilliam's deep appreciation of the book. "The Man Who Killed Don Quixote" works best as an exuberant, not always disciplined work of critical appropriation.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Don Quixote turns out to be a pretty typical Gilliam film: whimsically daffy, frantically overstuffed, and art-directed to within in an inch of its life. It's often transporting, but even more often exhausting.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Perhaps after all these years The Man Who Killed Don Quixote was never going to live up to the movie we'd built in our heads. Maybe that was an impossible dream.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Adam Driver brings a Nicolas Cage-esque zeal to his terrifically loony performance as Toby.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Witty, goofy, and glorious, The Man Who Killed Don Quixote is Terry Gilliam's best film in two decades.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: By the end of Terry Gilliam's film, Cervantes's heroes are at last free to move beyond representative confinement and once more speak freely as equals.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Thinking how different the world feels from even five years ago, let alone 25, the movie feels at a remove, not so much dated as just distanced, needlessly off on its own.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Visually heroic, narratively tilting at windmills, Terry Gilliam's 25-year obsession with Miguel de Cervantes' eccentric knight-errant embraces illusion with such devotion I ended up liking The Man Who Killed Don Quixote more than fighting it.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: A thoroughly middle-of-the-road effort, it may have been inevitable that actually watching director Terry Gilliam's cinematic great white whale would be a bit of a letdown after 30 years of myth-making.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: A treat.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Even if it doesn't always come together, it does entertain, bearing all the hallmarks of Gilliam's gleefully barmiest projects.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: A film suffused with a love of art, and of those who would dare to make it.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: There is so much goodwill towards Gilliam's quixotic Quixote project that it's easy to forgive its problems, of which there are many.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: There's enough of a germ of something in Don Quixote that you find yourself shaking your head by its climax, wondering, wait, what were we talking about again?

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It's as if Gilliam is pulling us into his madness, into a world where things are both better and more dangerous.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Even when the film feels like a circuitous, effortful mess, it's often an intentional one...

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It is an intensely personal piece of filmmaking, a movie shot through with sneaky, unruly pleasures and no small poignancy.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Strangely for such a labour of love, is that it's missing a bit of soul.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: It's clear that Gilliam developed a genuine relationship to this material from his own creative yearning.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Neither as bad as you fear nor as good as it deserves to be given the sheer effort of will that went into getting it made, it is enough that The Man Who Killed Don Quixote lives.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: Rarely have such brave deeds yielded so meager a reward.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: If anything, it's what the director's fans most feared: a lumbering, confused, and cacophonous mess.

movie: The Man Who Killed Don Quixote
reviews: What a dull place the world would be without Terry Gilliam.

Book-based film has mature themes, inspiring messages.
Christmas Jars will definitely be something families can watch together for a cheesy batch of Christmas feels!
Surprisingly entertaining... for a softcore porn soap opera flick.

It's heart is in the right place in many ways, but it just outlines everything so clearly in red marker that it doesn't let you discovers things for yourself. Still, it's an estimable effort in some ways.
That everything ends on a weird happy-clappy high is indicative of a scattershot project that could have done with less ambition, more focus.
The Public presents a heartening story of triumph of good over evil, but sadly lacks the gravitas one would usually expect from these types of stories.
It's all a bit old-fashioned and earnest but with US civil liberties under attack, it's a timely celebration of humanity.
It is a film with its heart in the right place, but the dialogue and characterisation are both plonkingly unconvincing.

Making a feature that pleads the cause of the homeless is a laudable achievement, so it's all the more unfortunate that Estevez is unable to eliminate some of the obvious flaws in an otherwise compelling, and timely, drama.
It's hard to play a good man doing the right thing. Saints are dramatically dull, but Estevez gets away with it here.
Estevez's drama gets a little preachy in the second half, but "The Public" is passionate about its cause and the cast... deliver like the pros they are.
Alec Baldwin, Jeffrey Wright, Christian Slater and Gabrielle Union all look like they'd rather be somewhere else.
Writer-director-star Emilio Estevez turns a library occupied by homeless citizens as ground zero for our under-fire democracy. Bravo!

The story's moral has obviousness problems, the plot's predictable, and its sweetness will annoy as many as it pleases. But it's still warm, winsome and droll, and the spectacular cast fills underwritten roles with radiant star power.
The problem is, there's only just enough story to go round. You can hear the creak as both characters and subplots get jacked up out of proportion.
Its heart is in the right place, but because it's mired in too many of Estevez's questions about public duty versus public safety, The Public struggles to stay on track and keep the viewer involved.
It's a noble effort, but "The Public" never makes a convincing case for its cause.
Its presentation of real, painful issues is too simplistic and its approach too preachy.
Estevez does an elegant job with this setup, creating a low-key, uncondescending portrait of lives on the edge.
Well-intentioned parable about the plight of the homeless falls flat.
Estevez, directing himself, knows what emotions Estevez, the actor, is trying to put over. He's the only one.

It's hard to disagree with anything in "The Public." Estevez is fighting the good fight. But it's also hard to swallow an argument, however well-reasoned and emotionally compelling, when it feels like it's being shoved down your throat.
A clunky and at times ridiculous affair, taking a situation that might reasonably happen and turning it into something melodramatic and ultimately unbelievable.
[A]n often implausible, stacked deck of social issues, contrived conflicts and feel-good activism.
The film is a clunky, overwritten attempt to pack as many tortured subplots and pre-chewed sociological insights as can possibly fit into a two-hour runtime.
Humorous, impactful and poignant. With a little extra tooling, it would also make a great Broadway play.
Consistently engages despite the relative obviousness of its dramatic tactics.
The dialogue often has a stilted, unnatural ring to it, and it is a tribute to the cast that they manage to bring out the essence of the film, its political heart, so strongly.

All the corny romance stuff is about as intrinsic to the film’s soft appeal as the scrupulously well-made frocks, encompassing late Edwardian lace and flapper-style dropwaist numbers, and dozens of well-turned cloche hats.
If "The Chaperone" accomplishes anything, that will be to send viewers scrambling to Google to learn more about this extraordinary woman.
I'm not an Elizabeth McGovern completist, but it may be the best thing she's ever done.
This is a coming-of-age story for both women. The title is fitting.
"The Chaperone" is like telling the Tiger Woods story by choosing to focus on his first caddy. Sure, it's a way in, but unless that caddy has a really good story, what are we doing here?
Norma's story, as handmaid to greatness, inevitably ends up feeling like we've explored a pleasant tributary, rather than the mainstream.
Between the speakeasies, the orphanages, the sexual energy, and the general air of corset-loosening, the movie should throb and thrum. It doesn't.

The focus isn't on the bratty flapper but McGovern's character's hesitant, poignant attempt to find out what she wants to be when she grows up, in a time and place where nobody wants her to be much of anything at all.
Despite the best efforts of McGovern et al., The Chaperone is lightweight trifle.
Because The Chaperone's second fiddle doesn't soak up the spotlight as readily as its star, the film leaves the viewer with an unsatisfied longing for more Brooks.
The film has a sedate TV-movie quality, unbefitting of the roaring era and its It Girl.
The movie does have an intelligent TV feel in its technique, with its focus on actors' faces and on acting moments that can be easily seen, even on a small screen.
Yet despite the stirring performance at its heart, the movie is ultimately too restricted by its own dramatic conventions, and it only seldom comes to life.
Self-actualization may be essential for people, but it doesn't always make for the best of drama.
Masterpiece Theater's first foray into theaters argues that the venerable program should continue to showcase long-form television rather than expanding into a format for which it is ill-suited.
It's a small-scale movie, and no harm in that, but it's tidy and stagy in a fusty middlebrow way.
A film of uncommon rapture, albeit one with little of the noisy, fast-moving action contemporary audiences have come to expect.
What makes Engler's film worth a look, apart from its two leading ladies, is how it manages to make a tale set nearly a century ago feel oddly timely.
If it's too much to ask for a Richardson-starring Louise Brooks biopic, is it then too much ask for a true two-hander in which she and McGovern actually share the screen? Apparently, and sadly, yes.
While Norma awakens to fresh possibilities, her story remains a snooze.
Though Richardson is a delight, her verve and sexual confidence only highlight the dreariness around her. A light goes out whenever she's offscreen.
It's little more than a handsome snooze that even the Masterpiece Theatre crowd may find a bit too snoozy.
Until the last half-hour, it's a rather plodding process of experimentation and assimilation as Norma gains the insight and courage to seize her dreams.

movie: Nancy Drew and the Hidden S…
reviews: Nancy Drew and the Hidden Staircase is a pleasing return to the kind of storytelling captured in those books, in which a mystery is tidily solved through logic and cleverness.

movie: Nancy Drew and the Hidden S…
reviews: Lillis shines as the brainy detective, but the movie itself is none too bright.

movie: Nancy Drew and the Hidden S…
reviews: Ineffectual, irrelevant and amateurishly conceived from start to finish, this movie is so bad it could kill off Nancy Drew forever.

movie: Nancy Drew and the Hidden S…
reviews: Lillis is ideally cast as Nancy, often cheerfully undercutting some of her character's more precocious proclamations, cracking smiles and reminding us that she's still a kid.

movie: Nancy Drew and the Hidden S…
reviews: [Lillis is] the freshest thing to happen to Nancy Drew in decades, making it clear that casting was the solution that has so often eluded this series in its jump from page to screen in the past.

movie: Nancy Drew and the Hidden S…

Though it's a familiar plot about kids learning discipline and teamwork through sports, The Grizzlies is brought to life through the specifics that make the characters and their sense of place -- and of displacement -- central to the story.
It's exactly the type of uplifting movie that could boost spirits during these bleak times.
Bracingly unsentimental and transcendently moving at the same time.

It's a fascinating puzzle: a film that is simultaneously an indictment of the toxic legacy of cultural imperialism and a weepie that employs the familiar tropes of Hollywood, one of the biggest machines of cultural imperialism on the planet.
